intuition: The proportion of a vertex's neighbours which are in its own group.
limitations: - Interpretation can depend heavily on the relative sizes of the groups. (For example $H_i=0.5$ might imply significant polarisation if $A_i$ is small (say, 10% of the population), but would be consistent with no homophily if $A_i$ is 50% of the population.)

intuition: An average measure of the degree to which vertices in a group are connected to vertices in their own group, rather than others.
limitations: Interpretation can depend heavily on the relative sizes of the groups. For example $H_i=0.5$ might imply significant polarisation if $A_i$ is small (say, 10% of the population), but would be Consistent with no homophily if $A_i$ is 50% of the population.

intuition: An average measure of the degree to which all vertices are connected to vertices in their own group, rather than others.
limitations: Interpretation can depend heavily on the relative sizes of the groups. For example $H_i=0.5$ might imply significant polarisation if $A_i$ is small (say, 10% of the population), but would be Consistent with no homophily if $A_i$ is 50% of the population.

intuition: The number of intra-group edges in the graph minus the expected number of intra-group edges in a graph with the same nodes, groups and degrees, but with edges placed at random. (Up to a multiplicative constant.)
formula: $$\frac{1}{4|E|} \sum_{u,v\in V, v\neq u} \left[\mathbf{1}((u,v)\in E)-\frac{d(u)d(v)}{2|E|}\right] \mathbf{1}(u,v\text{ in same group})$$

intuition: The difference between the proportions of edges that are inter- and intra-group.
Given that two random walks ended in different groups, the difference between the probability that they started from those same groups and the probability that they started from different groups.
formula: $$\begin{eqnarray}&\mathbf{P}(R_1(\mathsf{start})\in G_1, R_2(\mathsf{start})\in G_2 \mid R_1(\mathsf{end})\in G_1, R_2(\mathsf{end})\in G_2)\\  &- \mathbf{P}( R_1(\mathsf{start})\in G_2, R_2(\mathsf{start})\in G_1 \mid R_1(\mathsf{end})\in G_1, R_2(\mathsf{end})\in G_2 )\end{eqnarray}$$
limitations: Some argue that it is not capable of detecting controversy using only structural data. Propose a "biased random walk" that also incorporates content information.

intuition: The probability that a random walk which ends in one group started at the vertex of interest, relative to the same value for other groups.
limitations: Some argue that it is not capable of detecting controversy using only structural data. Propose a "biased random walk" that also incorporates content information.

intuition: Degree of consistency with properties such as "my friend's friend is my friend" and "my friend's enemy is my enemy".
Minimum number of edge modifications that must be made to be perfectly consistent with properties such as "my friend's friend is my friend" and "my friend's enemy is my enemy".
Minimum number of vertices which must be deleted to be perfectly consistent with properties such as "my friend's friend is my friend" and "my friend's enemy is my enemy".
The maximum distance between any two points.
limitations:
- Insensitive to the shape of the distribution.
- Does not consider whether the agents at the boundaries are outliers or the edges of large clusters.

intuition: The volume of the minimal convex polytope that includes all points.
limitations:
- Insensitive to the shape of the distribution.
- Does not consider whether the agents at the boundaries are outliers or the edges of large clusters.

intuition: Average pairwise distance between any two points.
Average distance between each point and the mean.
Scalar standard deviation of the set of points.
Scalar variance of the set of points.
Scalar standard deviation divided by the mean.
The number of distinct attitudes held or the variety of attitudes that at least one person in the population holds.
The number of groups.
limitations: - Really this is a set of metrics, not just one. Depends heavily on the clustering algorithm used.

intuition: Average pairwise $p$-value in pairwise hypothesis tests for the difference between two groups.
formula: $$ \frac{1}{M\choose 2} \sum_{i < j} \textsf{pValue}(H_1: G_i \neq G_j \text{ against } H_0: G_i = G_j)$$

intuition: Average pairwise distance (using a probability metric) between the distributions of groups.
The extent to which a distribution is bimodal or multimodal.
formula: There are a number of existing measures—see references.

intuition: Average pairwise distance between group means.
Average distance between an individual and the mean of their group, averaged across groups.
A measure of polarization based only on the proportions of points in each group.
